message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0
Paper Abstract: The SCIP Optimization Suite provides a collection of software packages for mathematical optimization, centered around the constraint integer programming (CIP) framework SCIP. This report discusses the enhancements and extensions included in the SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0. The updates in SCIP 9.0 include improved symmetry handling, additions and improvements of nonlinear handlers and primal heuristics, a new cut generator and two new cut selection schemes, a new branching rule, a new LP interface, and several bug fixes. The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0 also features new Rust and C++ interfaces for SCIP, new Python interface for SoPlex, along with enhancements to existing interfaces. The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0 also includes new and improved features in the LP solver SoPlex, the presolving library PaPILO, the parallel framework UG, the decomposition framework GCG, and the SCIP extension SCIP-SDP. These additions and enhancements have resulted in an overall performance improvement of SCIP in terms of solving time, number of nodes in the branch-and-bound tree, as well as the reliability of the solver.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "cutting plane method"

Links: [{"title":"Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Talk:Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Plane (tool) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plane_(tool)"},{"title":"Stretched grid method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stretched_grid_method"},{"title":"Adrian Baddeley - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Baddeley"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the cutting plane method:

## Definition

In mathematical optimization, the cutting-plane method is any of a variety of optimization methods that iteratively refine a feasible set or objective function by means of linear inequalities, termed cuts.

## Applications

Such procedures are commonly used to find integer solutions to mixed integer linear programming (MILP) problems, as well as to solve general, not necessarily differentiable convex optimization problems.(no content)Cutting plane methods are also applicable in nonlinear programming.

## History

The use of cutting planes to solve MILP was introduced by Ralph E. Gomory.(no content)Cutting planes were proposed by Ralph Gomory in the 1950s as a method for solving integer programming and mixed-integer programming problems.

## Modern Usage

Nowadays, all commercial MILP solvers use Gomory cuts in one way or another.

The method works by starting with a relaxed version of the optimization problem and then iteratively adding constraints to narrow down the solution space until an optimal integer solution is found.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of constraint integer programming:

## Key Concepts

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers. In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.(no content)If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Solving Methods

One class of algorithms used to solve integer linear programs are cutting plane methods, which work by solving the LP relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points.(no content)Another class of algorithms are variants of the branch and bound method, for example, the branch and cut method that combines both branch and bound and cutting plane methods.

## Related Paradigms

It's worth noting that constraint programming is a related but distinct approach. Constraint programming (CP) is a paradigm for solving combinatorial problems that draws on a wide range of techniques from artificial intelligence, computer science, and operations research. Additionally, Google OR-Tools is a free and open-source software suite developed by Google for solving linear programming (LP), mixed integer programming (MIP), constraint programming (CP), vehicle routing (VRP), and related optimization problems.

I've performed the web search for "heuristic algorithm" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

A heuristic is a technique designed for problem solving more quickly when classic methods are too slow for finding an exact or approximate solution, or when classic methods fail to find any exact solution in a search space. This is achieved by trading optimality, completeness, accuracy, or precision for speed.

## Purpose and Objective

The objective of a heuristic is to produce a solution in a reasonable time frame that is good enough for solving the problem at hand.(no content)This solution may not be the best of all the solutions to this problem, or it may simply approximate the exact solution. But it is still valuable because finding it does not require a prohibitively long time.

## Function in Algorithms

A heuristic function is a function that ranks alternatives in search algorithms at each branching step based on available information to decide which branch to follow.

## Practical Applications

Results about NP-hardness in theoretical computer science make heuristics the only viable option for a variety of complex optimization problems that need to be routinely solved in real-world applications. Common heuristic algorithms include the greedy algorithm, A* search algorithm, and various metaheuristic approaches.

The objective of a heuristic is to produce a solution in a reasonable time frame that is good enough for solving the problem at hand.(no content)This solution may not be the best of all the solutions to this problem, or it may simply approximate the exact solution. But it is still valuable because finding it does not require a prohibitively long time.

## Function in Algorithms

A heuristic function is a function that ranks alternatives in search algorithms at each branching step based on available information to decide which branch to follow.

## Practical Applications

Results about NP-hardness in theoretical computer science make heuristics the only viable option for a variety of complex optimization problems that need to be routinely solved in real-world applications. Common heuristic algorithms include the greedy algorithm, A* search algorithm, and various metaheuristic approaches.

## Overview

Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships.

## Common Linear Programming Solvers

There are several widely-used solvers available:

**Open-Source Solvers:**
- GLOP (the Google Linear Optimization Package) is Google's open-source linear programming solver, written in C++ and released as part of Google's OR-Tools software suite in 2014.
- COIN-OR LP (CLP) is an open-source linear programming solver written in C++.
- The GNU Linear Programming Kit (GLPK) is a software package intended for solving large-scale linear programming (LP) and mixed integer programming (MIP) problems, organized as a callable library.

**Commercial Solvers:**
- Gurobi Optimizer is a solver for linear and quadratic programming with continuous or integer variables (MIP).
- The FICO Xpress optimizer is a commercial optimization solver for linear programming (LP), mixed integer linear programming (MILP), and other problem types.

**Modeling Languages:**
- AMPL (A Mathematical Programming Language) is an algebraic modeling language for large-scale optimization and scheduling problems that supports dozens of solvers, both open source and commercial, including CPLEX, MOSEK, and IPOPT.

## Solution Methods

The current opinion is that the efficiencies of good implementations of simplex-based methods and interior point methods are similar for routine applications of linear programming.

Web search results for query: "branch and bound algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"Joint compatibility branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_compatibility_branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Travelling salesman problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem"},{"title":"Talk:Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Talk:Uniform-cost search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uniform-cost_search"},{"title":"B* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B*"},{"title":"Shifting bottleneck heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shifting_bottleneck_heuristic"}]

## Branch and Bound Algorithm

Branch-and-bound (BB, B&B, or BnB) is a method for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller subproblems and using a bounding function to eliminate subproblems that cannot contain the optimal solution.(no content)It is an algorithm design paradigm for discrete and combinatorial optimization problems, as well as mathematical optimization.

### How It Works

A branch-and-bound algorithm consists of a systematic enumeration of candidate solutions by means of state-space search: the set of candidate solutions is thought of as forming a rooted tree with the full set at the root. The algorithm explores branches of this tree, which represent subsets of the solution set.(no content)Before enumerating the candidate solutions of a branch, the branch is checked against upper and lower estimated bounds on the optimal solution, and is discarded if it cannot produce a better solution than the best one found so far by the algorithm.

### Key Concept

To improve on the performance of brute-force search, a B&B algorithm keeps track of bounds on the minimum that it is trying to find, and uses these bounds to "prune" the search space, eliminating candidate solutions that it can prove will not contain an optimal solution.

### History

The method was first proposed by Ailsa Land and Alison Doig whilst carrying out research at the London School of Economics sponsored by British Petroleum in 1960 for discrete programming, and has become the most commonly used tool for solving NP-hard optimization problems.

### Applications

Branch-and-bound has been successfully applied to various problems, including the traveling salesman problem and integer linear programming optimization challenges.

Links: [{"title":"Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization"},{"title":"Category:Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Mathematical_optimization"},{"title":"Category:Mathematical optimization software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Mathematical_optimization_software"},{"title":"Category:Mathematical optimization in business - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Mathematical_optimization_in_business"},{"title":"Category:Mathematical Optimization Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Mathematical_Optimization_Society"},{"title":"Discrete optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_optimization"},{"title":"Optimization (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimization_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Combinatorial optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_optimization"},{"title":"Constrained optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constrained_optimization"},{"title":"List of optimization software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_optimization_software"}]

Here are the key findings from the web search on mathematical optimization:

## Definition

Mathematical optimization (alternatively spelled optimisation) or mathematical programming is the selection of a best element, with regard to some criteria, from some set of available alternatives.

## Main Divisions

It is generally divided into two subfields: discrete optimization and continuous optimization.

## Key Types of Optimization

Several important categories include:

- **Discrete Optimization**: Some or all of the variables used in a discrete optimization problem are restricted to be discrete variables—that is, to assume only a discrete set of values, such as the integers.

- **Combinatorial Optimization**: Combinatorial optimization consists of finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects, where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a discrete set.(no content)Typical combinatorial optimization problems are the travelling salesman problem ("TSP"), the minimum spanning tree problem ("MST"), and the knapsack problem.

- **Constrained Optimization**: Constrained optimization is the process of optimizing an objective function with respect to some variables in the presence of constraints on those variables.

## Historical Context

The term "linear programming" for certain optimization cases was due to George B. Dantzig, although much of the theory had been introduced by Leonid Kantorovich in 1939.

This field has broad applications across business, engineering, computer science, and many other areas.

Links: [{"title":"Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization"},{"title":"Category:Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Mathematical_optimization"},{"title":"Category:Mathematical optimization software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Mathematical_optimization_software"},{"title":"Category:Mathematical optimization in business - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Mathematical_optimization_in_business"},{"title":"Category:Mathematical Optimization Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Mathematical_Optimization_Society"},{"title":"Discrete optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_optimization"},{"title":"Optimization (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimization_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Combinatorial optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_optimization"},{"title":"Constrained optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constrained_optimization"},{"title":"List of optimization software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_optimization_software"}]

Here are the key findings from the web search on mathematical optimization:

## Definition

Mathematical optimization (alternatively spelled optimisation) or mathematical programming is the selection of a best element, with regard to some criteria, from some set of available alternatives.

## Main Divisions

It is generally divided into two subfields: discrete optimization and continuous optimization.

## Key Types of Optimization

Several important categories include:

- **Discrete Optimization**: Some or all of the variables used in a discrete optimization problem are restricted to be discrete variables—that is, to assume only a discrete set of values, such as the integers.

- **Combinatorial Optimization**: Combinatorial optimization consists of finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects, where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a discrete set.(no content)Typical combinatorial optimization problems are the travelling salesman problem ("TSP"), the minimum spanning tree problem ("MST"), and the knapsack problem.

- **Constrained Optimization**: Constrained optimization is the process of optimizing an objective function with respect to some variables in the presence of constraints on those variables.

## Historical Context

The term "linear programming" for certain optimization cases was due to George B. Dantzig, although much of the theory had been introduced by Leonid Kantorovich in 1939.

This field has broad applications across business, engineering, computer science, and many other areas.

Web search results for query: "branching algorithm optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"Edmonds' algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmonds'_algorithm"},{"title":"Branching factor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branching_factor"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"Branch-decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch-decomposition"},{"title":"Branch predictor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_predictor"},{"title":"Branch (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Alpha–beta pruning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpha–beta_pruning"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of branching algorithm optimization:

## Key Branching Optimization Techniques

**Branch and Bound**: This is a method for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller subproblems and using a bounding function to eliminate subproblems that cannot contain the optimal solution.(no content)A B&B algorithm keeps track of bounds on the minimum that it is trying to find, and uses these bounds to "prune" the search space, eliminating candidate solutions that it can prove will not contain an optimal solution.

**Branch and Cut**: This is a method of combinatorial optimization for solving integer linear programs (ILPs), that is, linear programming (LP) problems where some or all the unknowns are restricted to integer values. Branch and cut involves running a branch and bound algorithm and using cutting planes to tighten the linear programming relaxations.

**Branch and Price**: This is a method of combinatorial optimization for solving integer linear programming (ILP) and mixed integer linear programming (MILP) problems with many variables. The method is a hybrid of branch and bound and column generation methods.

**Alpha-Beta Pruning**: Alpha–beta pruning is a search algorithm that seeks to decrease the number of nodes that are evaluated by the minimax algorithm in its search tree. It is an adversarial search algorithm used commonly for machine playing of two-player combinatorial games.

**Branching Factor Reduction**: The branching factor can be cut down by a pruning algorithm.

**Variable Selection Strategies**: Some strategies choose the variable that is predicted to have the most change on the objective function based on past changes when it was chosen as the branching variable.

These techniques are fundamental to solving complex optimization and combinatorial problems efficiently by reducing the search space and avoiding exhaustive enumeration.

Web search results for query: "integer programming"

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"MINTO - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MINTO"},{"title":"Randomized rounding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_rounding"},{"title":"Laurence Wolsey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurence_Wolsey"},{"title":"Discrete optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_optimization"},{"title":"COIN-OR - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COIN-OR"},{"title":"List of optimization software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_optimization_software"},{"title":"Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about integer programming:

## Definition

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers.(no content)In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

## Key Variants

If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem. Additionally, 0–1 integer programming or binary integer programming (BIP) is the special case of integer programming where variables are required to be 0 or 1 (rather than arbitrary integers).

## Computational Complexity

Integer programming is NP-complete, and integer programming problems are in many practical situations (those with bounded variables) NP-hard.

## Practical Applications

Integer programming has numerous real-world applications:

- The integer variables represent quantities that can only be integer. For example, it is not possible to build 3.7 cars.
- Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling. One important example happens in agricultural production planning and involves determining production yield for several crops that can share resources (e.g. land, labor, capital, seeds, fertilizer, etc.).
- These problems involve service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks. For example, a problem may involve assigning buses or subways to individual routes so that a timetable can be met, and also to equip them with drivers.

## Solution Methods

The use of cutting planes to solve MILP was introduced by Ralph E. Gomory. Additionally, in the mid-1990s Gérard Cornuéjols and co-workers showed them to be very effective in combination with branch-and-bound (called branch-and-cut) and ways to overcome numerical instabilities.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
